content: Introduced in 2007, the Workfare Income Supplement is a broad-based measure that tops up the salaries of lower-income workers to help them save for retirement.Workfare is targeted at Singaporean workers whose earnings are in the bottom 20%, with some support for those slightly above.Over S$9.5 billion* of WIS has been disbursed to 990,000* lower-income workers.Workfare is paid in the form of CPF payments and cash to supplement their incomes.

metadata.header:
Workfare Income Supplement

Helping you save for the future

About Workfare
metadata.content: Introduced in 2007, the Workfare Income Supplement is a broad-based measure that tops up the salaries of lower-income workers to help them save for retirement.Workfare is targeted at Singaporean workers whose earnings are in the bottom 20%, with some support for those slightly above.Over S$9.5 billion* of WIS has been disbursed to 990,000* lower-income workers.Workfare is paid in the form of CPF payments and cash to supplement their incomes.

content: The Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) scheme encourages eligible workers to work and build up their CPF savings by providing them with cash payments and additional CPF contributions.

metadata.header:
Workfare Income Supplement

Boost your savings with Workfare Income Supplement

WIS
metadata.content: The Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) scheme encourages eligible workers to work and build up their CPF savings by providing them with cash payments and additional CPF contributions.

metadata.header:
Workfare Income Supplement

content:
- a Singapore Citizen 
 - at least 30 years old (previously 35 years old) as of 31 December of the work year, or persons with disabilities of any age 
 - earn a gross monthly income of at least $500, but not more than $2,500 (previously $2,300) for the month worked and in the past 12 months (average gross monthly income) as an employee

metadata.header:
Workfare Income Supplement

WIS for employees

Eligibility
metadata.content:
- a Singapore Citizen

content:
- live in a property with an annual value of more than $13,000 (assessed as at 31 December of the preceding year)
  - own two or more properties
 - are married, and you and your spouse own two or more properties together, or your spouse's income for the preceding year of assessment exceeds $70,000.

metadata.header:
Workfare Income Supplement

WIS for employees

You are not eligible for WIS if you
metadata.content:
- live in a property with an annual value of more than $13,000 (assessed as at 31 December of the preceding year)
  - own two or more properties
 - are married, and you and your spouse own two or more properties together, or your spouse's income for the preceding year of assessment exceeds $70,000.

content: You will receive 40% of your WIS in cash and 60% in CPF contributions. We will credit the cash portion to your PayNow NRIC-linked bank account if you have one. Otherwise, it will be credited to the bank account that you have registered to receive Government benefits, or via GovCash if you had not registered a bank account with us. If you need to update your local bank account details, you can do so after logging in to the e-Services.

metadata.header:
Workfare Income Supplement

Receiving WIS payments

How WIS payments are allocated
metadata.content: You will receive 40% of your WIS in cash and 60% in CPF contributions. We will credit the cash portion to your PayNow NRIC-linked bank account if you have one. Otherwise, it will be credited to the bank account that you have registered to receive Government benefits, or via GovCash if you had not registered a bank account with us. If you need to update your local bank account details, you can do so after logging in to the e-Services.

content: We will automatically assess your eligibility for WIS based on the CPF contributions made by your employer. If your employer is not contributing CPF on your behalf, please approach your employer to clarify on the discrepancies. If your employer does not provide you with a satisfactory response, you can lodge a report with CPF Board.

metadata.header:
Workfare Income Supplement

Actions required

If you are an employee, there’s no further action required
metadata.content: We will automatically assess your eligibility for WIS based on the CPF contributions made by your employer. If your employer is not contributing CPF on your behalf, please approach your employer to clarify on the discrepancies. If your employer does not provide you with a satisfactory response, you can lodge a report with CPF Board.

content: You will first be assessed for your work done as an employee and you will receive monthly WIS if you meet the criteria. After the work year, we will assess your eligibility for additional WIS, based on your total income for the year (both employee and self-employed income).

metadata.header:
Workfare Income Supplement

Actions required

If you worked as both an employee and a self-employed person,
metadata.content: You will first be assessed for your work done as an employee and you will receive monthly WIS if you meet the criteria. After the work year, we will assess your eligibility for additional WIS, based on your total income for the year (both employee and self-employed income).

content: For individuals aged 30-34, WIS payments were not applicable in 2022, but from 2023, they will receive $2,100. Those aged 35-44 will see an increase from $1,700 in 2022 to $3,000 from 2023. The age group 45-54 is eligible for $2,500 in 2022, which increases to $3,600 from 2023. Individuals aged 55-59 will receive an increase from $3,300 in 2022 to $3,600 from 2023. For those 60 and above, the WIS payment goes from $4,000 in 2022 to $4,200 from 2023. Additionally, persons with disabilities will receive the same amount as those who are aged 60 and above, irrespective of their actual age.

metadata.header:
Workfare Income Supplement

Your WIS payments

Maximum WIS amount you can receive each year, based on your age group.
metadata.content: For individuals aged 30-34, WIS payments were not applicable in 2022, but from 2023, they will receive $2,100. Those aged 35-44 will see an increase from $1,700 in 2022 to $3,000 from 2023. The age group 45-54 is eligible for $2,500 in 2022, which increases to $3,600 from 2023. Individuals aged 55-59 will receive an increase from $3,300 in 2022 to $3,600 from 2023. For those 60 and above, the WIS payment goes from $4,000 in 2022 to $4,200 from 2023. Additionally, persons with disabilities will receive the same amount as those who are aged 60 and above, irrespective of their actual age.

content: If you work in January, you'll receive the WIS by the end of March if paid through PayNow-NRIC/Bank Crediting, or in the first week of April if via GovCash. For work done in February, WIS is paid by the end of April or the first week of May, and for March, it's the end of May or the first week of June. This pattern continues similarly for other months, with WIS payments made two months after the work month for PayNow-NRIC/Bank Crediting and three months later for GovCash.

metadata.header:
Workfare Income Supplement

Payment schedule

As an employee, you will receive WIS every month.
metadata.content: If you work in January, you'll receive the WIS by the end of March if paid through PayNow-NRIC/Bank Crediting, or in the first week of April if via GovCash. For work done in February, WIS is paid by the end of April or the first week of May, and for March, it's the end of May or the first week of June. This pattern continues similarly for other months, with WIS payments made two months after the work month for PayNow-NRIC/Bank Crediting and three months later for GovCash.

content: To be eligible for the Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) in Singapore, you must be a Singapore Citizen and at least 30 years old by the end of the work year, or a person with disabilities of any age. This age requirement was previously set at 35 for work done before 2023. Additionally, you need to earn an average monthly income of at least $500 (for work done from 2023 onwards) but not exceed $2,500, with the previous upper limit being $2,300 for work done before 2023. Also, you must have declared your net trade income and contributed to MediSave.

metadata.header:
Workfare Income Supplement

WIS for self-employed persons

Eligibility
metadata.content: To be eligible for the Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) in Singapore, you must be a Singapore Citizen and at least 30 years old by the end of the work year, or a person with disabilities of any age. This age requirement was previously set at 35 for work done before 2023. Additionally, you need to earn an average monthly income of at least $500 (for work done from 2023 onwards) but not exceed $2,500, with the previous upper limit being $2,300 for work done before 2023. Also, you must have declared your net trade income and contributed to MediSave.

content: The conditions specify that you must live in a property valued over $13,000 annually (assessed as of December 31st of the preceding year), own two or more properties, and if married, you and your spouse collectively own two or more properties, or your spouse's income in the previous year exceeded $70,000.

metadata.header:
Workfare Income Supplement

WIS for self-employed persons

You are not eligible for WIS if you:
metadata.content: The conditions specify that you must live in a property valued over $13,000 annually (assessed as of December 31st of the preceding year), own two or more properties, and if married, you and your spouse collectively own two or more properties, or your spouse's income in the previous year exceeded $70,000.

content: You will receive 10% of your WIS in cash and 90% in your MediSave account. We will credit the cash portion into your PayNow NRIC-linked bank account if you have one. Otherwise, it will be credited to the bank account that you have registered to receive Government benefits, or via GovCash if you had not registered a bank account with us. If you need to update your bank account details, you can do so after logging into the e-Services.

metadata.header:
Workfare Income Supplement

Receiving WIS payments

WIS for self-employed persons
metadata.content: You will receive 10% of your WIS in cash and 90% in your MediSave account. We will credit the cash portion into your PayNow NRIC-linked bank account if you have one. Otherwise, it will be credited to the bank account that you have registered to receive Government benefits, or via GovCash if you had not registered a bank account with us. If you need to update your bank account details, you can do so after logging into the e-Services.

content:
For Work Year 2023 (WY2023) onwards
 All Net Trade Income (NTI) declarations for Work Year 2023 (Year of Assessment 2024) can be made with the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) by filing a tax return. There is no need to file separate declarations with CPF Board. If you receive a notification (via letter/form/SMS) to file tax from IRAS, or you meet the requirement to file tax (i.e. NTI above $6,000 and/or Total Income above $22,000), please complete and submit the tax return to IRAS directly. The income tax filing period is from 1 March to 18 April annually. If you do not receive a notification from IRAS or do not meet the requirement to file tax, you can declare your self-employed NTI to IRAS via myTax Portal which will be available from 1 March to 31 October annually for taxpayers to e-File tax returns. Once IRAS has assessed your income for the year, your assessed NTI will be transmitted to the Board. You can check your updated NTI records by logging in to the Self-employment dashboard with your Singpass. 
 For Work Year 2022 (WY2022) or earlier. If you were not issued a Notice of Assessment (NOA) by IRAS and wish to declare NTI for work years prior to 2023, you can write to us via My Mailbox using your Singpass. If you have declared your NTI with IRAS, you need not declare your income again to the Board. Make sure you’ve made the required contributions into your MediSave account.

metadata.header:
Workfare Income Supplement

Actions required

WIS for self-employed persons
metadata.content:
For Work Year 2023 (WY2023) onwards
 All Net Trade Income (NTI) declarations for Work Year 2023 (Year of Assessment 2024) can be made with the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) by filing a tax return. There is no need to file separate declarations with CPF Board. If you receive a notification (via letter/form/SMS) to file tax from IRAS, or you meet the requirement to file tax (i.e. NTI above $6,000 and/or Total Income above $22,000), please complete and submit the tax return to IRAS directly. The income tax filing period is from 1 March to 18 April annually. If you do not receive a notification from IRAS or do not meet the requirement to file tax, you can declare your self-employed NTI to IRAS via myTax Portal which will be available from 1 March to 31 October annually for taxpayers to e-File tax returns. Once IRAS has assessed your income for the year, your assessed NTI will be transmitted to the Board. You can check your updated NTI records by logging in to the Self-employment dashboard with your Singpass. 
 For Work Year 2022 (WY2022) or earlier. If you were not issued a Notice of Assessment (NOA) by IRAS and wish to declare NTI for work years prior to 2023, you can write to us via My Mailbox using your Singpass. If you have declared your NTI with IRAS, you need not declare your income again to the Board. Make sure you’ve made the required contributions into your MediSave account.

content: For individuals aged 30-34, WIS was not applicable in 2022 but became $1,400 from 2023. Those aged 35-44 received $1,133 in 2022, which increased to $2,000 from 2023. The age group 45-54 was eligible for $1,667 in 2022, which increased to $2,400 from 2023. Individuals aged 55-59 received $2,200 in 2022, and for those 60 and above, it was $2,667 in 2022 and increased to $2,800 from 2023. Persons with disabilities receive the same amount as those aged 60 and above.

metadata.header:
Workfare Income Supplement

WIS for self-employed persons

maximum amount of WIS you can receive each year, based on your age group./h4>
metadata.content: For individuals aged 30-34, WIS was not applicable in 2022 but became $1,400 from 2023. Those aged 35-44 received $1,133 in 2022, which increased to $2,000 from 2023. The age group 45-54 was eligible for $1,667 in 2022, which increased to $2,400 from 2023. Individuals aged 55-59 received $2,200 in 2022, and for those 60 and above, it was $2,667 in 2022 and increased to $2,800 from 2023. Persons with disabilities receive the same amount as those aged 60 and above.

content: As an SEP, you will receive WIS payments once a year for work done in the preceding year. If you are an eligible Self-Employed Person (SEP), you will receive WIS once a year for work done in the preceding work year. The earliest payment for SEPs for a particular Work Year (WY) will be in end April of the following work year, provided you have declared your income and contributed to your MediSave by the following WY.

metadata.header:
Workfare Income Supplement

WIS for self-employed persons

When you will receive WIS payments
metadata.content: As an SEP, you will receive WIS payments once a year for work done in the preceding year. If you are an eligible Self-Employed Person (SEP), you will receive WIS once a year for work done in the preceding work year. The earliest payment for SEPs for a particular Work Year (WY) will be in end April of the following work year, provided you have declared your income and contributed to your MediSave by the following WY.

content: We will automatically assess your employees’ eligibility for WIS based on the CPF contributions you make. For more information such as Employer obligations and making CPF contributions, you may visit the Employer section. Find out more about your CPF obligations at the Ministry of Manpower (MOM) website on the Workright initiative.

metadata.header:
Workfare Income Supplement

What you need to know as an employer

EMPLOYER
metadata.content: We will automatically assess your employees’ eligibility for WIS based on the CPF contributions you make. For more information such as Employer obligations and making CPF contributions, you may visit the Employer section. Find out more about your CPF obligations at the Ministry of Manpower (MOM) website on the Workright initiative.

content: WIS encourages Singaporeans to work, making it easier for you to hire and retain local workers. WIS is fully paid for by the Government and doesn’t increase business costs for local enterprises.

metadata.header:
Workfare Income Supplement

What you need to know as an employer

How WIS helps employers
metadata.content: WIS encourages Singaporeans to work, making it easier for you to hire and retain local workers. WIS is fully paid for by the Government and doesn’t increase business costs for local enterprises.

content: To be eligible for the Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) scheme, you must be a Singapore Citizen and meet specific criteria: You should be at least 30 years old (or 35 for work done before 2023) or have disabilities, work within certain income limits, and declare Net Trade Income (NTI) if you're self-employed. However, you won't qualify if you live in a high-value property, own multiple properties, or meet certain income criteria as a married individual.

metadata.header:
Workfare Income Supplement

Am I eligible for the Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) scheme?
metadata.content: To be eligible for the Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) scheme, you must be a Singapore Citizen and meet specific criteria: You should be at least 30 years old (or 35 for work done before 2023) or have disabilities, work within certain income limits, and declare Net Trade Income (NTI) if you're self-employed. However, you won't qualify if you live in a high-value property, own multiple properties, or meet certain income criteria as a married individual.

content: If you are an employee, you do not need to do anything. Your eligibility for Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) will be automatically assessed based on the CPF contributions* made by your employer. If you are a Self-Employed Person (SEP), you will need to: declare your Net Trade Income (NTI) from Work Year 2023 to the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS). If you receive a notification (via letter/form/SMS) to file tax from IRAS, or you meet the requirement to file tax (i.e. NTI above $6,000 and/or Total Income above $22,000), please complete and submit the tax return to IRAS directly. The income tax filing period is from 1 March to 18 April annually. If you do not receive a notification from IRAS or do not meet the requirement to file tax, you may declare your self-employed NTI to IRAS via myTax Portal which will be available from 1 March to 31 October annually for taxpayers to e-File tax returns; and

metadata.header:
Workfare Income Supplement

What do I need to do to receive Workfare Income Supplement (WIS)?
metadata.content: If you are an employee, you do not need to do anything. Your eligibility for Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) will be automatically assessed based on the CPF contributions* made by your employer. If you are a Self-Employed Person (SEP), you will need to: declare your Net Trade Income (NTI) from Work Year 2023 to the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS). If you receive a notification (via letter/form/SMS) to file tax from IRAS, or you meet the requirement to file tax (i.e. NTI above $6,000 and/or Total Income above $22,000), please complete and submit the tax return to IRAS directly. The income tax filing period is from 1 March to 18 April annually. If you do not receive a notification from IRAS or do not meet the requirement to file tax, you may declare your self-employed NTI to IRAS via myTax Portal which will be available from 1 March to 31 October annually for taxpayers to e-File tax returns; and

content: Employed Individuals: For individuals aged 30-34, there was no WIS applicable in 2022. However, from 2023 onwards, they will receive $2,100. Those aged 35-44 saw an increase from $1,700 in 2022 to $3,000 from 2023. The age group 45-54 was eligible for $2,500 in 2022, which increased to $3,600 from 2023. Individuals aged 55-59 received an increase from $3,300 in 2022 to $3,600 from 2023. For those aged 60 and above, the WIS payment increased from $4,000 in 2022 to $4,200 from 2023. Persons with disabilities receive the same amount as those aged 60 and above, regardless of their actual age. Self-Employed Individuals: Self-employed individuals aged 30-34 had no applicable WIS in 2022, but they became eligible for $1,400 from 2023. Those aged 35-44 saw an increase from $1,133 in 2022 to $2,000 from 2023. The age group 45-54 was eligible for $1,667 in 2022, which increased to $2,400 from 2023. Individuals aged 55-59 received $2,200 in 2022 and continued to receive $2,400 from 2023. For those aged 60 and above, the WIS payment increased from $2,667 in 2022 to $2,800 from 2023. Similar to employed individuals, persons with disabilities in the self-employed category also receive the same amount as those aged 60 and above.

metadata.header:
Workfare Income Supplement

How much Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) will I get?
metadata.content: Employed Individuals: For individuals aged 30-34, there was no WIS applicable in 2022. However, from 2023 onwards, they will receive $2,100. Those aged 35-44 saw an increase from $1,700 in 2022 to $3,000 from 2023. The age group 45-54 was eligible for $2,500 in 2022, which increased to $3,600 from 2023. Individuals aged 55-59 received an increase from $3,300 in 2022 to $3,600 from 2023. For those aged 60 and above, the WIS payment increased from $4,000 in 2022 to $4,200 from 2023. Persons with disabilities receive the same amount as those aged 60 and above, regardless of their actual age. Self-Employed Individuals: Self-employed individuals aged 30-34 had no applicable WIS in 2022, but they became eligible for $1,400 from 2023. Those aged 35-44 saw an increase from $1,133 in 2022 to $2,000 from 2023. The age group 45-54 was eligible for $1,667 in 2022, which increased to $2,400 from 2023. Individuals aged 55-59 received $2,200 in 2022 and continued to receive $2,400 from 2023. For those aged 60 and above, the WIS payment increased from $2,667 in 2022 to $2,800 from 2023. Similar to employed individuals, persons with disabilities in the self-employed category also receive the same amount as those aged 60 and above.
